16/03/2022

The incoming YUSU President sets out his plans for the year ahead

Image by YUSU

By Luke Brown

Pierrick Roger,Â elected YUSU President in February, is a man on a mission.

He has spent the last year as YUSUâ€™s Environment Officer, managing to set up the new Sustainability Committee to push the University and YUSU to take practical action on environmental challenges.

â€œYUSU declaring a climate crisis isnâ€™t enough,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s just words unless we actually practise what we preach.â€

Indeed, Pierrick hasnâ€™t shied away from conflict as Environment Officer.

â€œThere are people in charge at YUSU who I often disagree with. It gets tense so often.â€

Pierrick has a history of being vocal about environmental issues. He has worked with Extinction Rebellion and York Strikes for Climate, amongst others, over the past four years. Fittingly, he is currently studying a Masters in Biology.

He credits his background with shaping his commitment to sustainability. Born in France but raised in Singapore, he understands the threat posed by climate change better than most.

â€œSingapore will be underwater by the end of this century,â€ he says. â€œIf you know your homeâ€™s going to disappear, it makes you take environmental problems more seriously.â€

Now Pierrick is set to start his new role as President in July, and to receive the Â£21,000 salary that comes with it. Pierrick will be the first BAME (black, asian and minority ethnicity) President in ten years, alongside two other BAME Sabbatical Officers. â€œSuch a big win for diversity,â€ he gushes.

What will be his priority from day one? â€œNon-disclosure agreements,â€ Pierrick says without hesitation. He calls them â€œhush agreementsâ€, as they prevent the staff and students that sign them from speaking out.

In particular, Pierrick is concerned with NDAs that YUSU has reportedly made some students sign in alleged sexual abuse cases. Given the confidential nature of the agreements, the scale of the problem is not clear.

Pierrick tells Nouse that several students approached him when he announced his candidacy to raise this issue: â€œIt wasnâ€™t something I was aware of until other students told me about it. Now that I know about it, itâ€™s a key priority for me.â€

To get to the bottom of the matter, Pierrick is planning to launch an investigation into YUSUâ€™s use of NDAs.

â€œI want to know how many have been used, and how many students are involved,â€ he declares. â€œWe shouldnâ€™t be silencing anyone. YUSU controls these agreements. We can change this, and Iâ€™m going to give it my best shot.â€

Patrick Oâ€™Donnell, the current YUSU President, said: â€œYUSU has never previously used, nor ever would use a non-disclosure agreement and we consider the use of legal gagging on student complaints to be both inappropriate and unnecessary. We look forward to working with incoming elected representatives to help them understand our processes and approach.

â€œWe routinely ask students to be mindful about confidentiality in relation to complaints processes but to be clear this is for the purpose of enabling unimpeded investigations to take place, and help ensure that no activity prejudices complaints or case work.

â€œThere may be genuine confusion with a national campaign to encourage universities to sign a pledge against the use of NDAs, and we are pleased that York was one of the first institutions to sign it.â€

After NDAs, sustainability is next on the list. Pierrick recognises that his â€œstructural changeâ€ during his tenure as Environment Officer is only a first step- â€œso far, it seems to be working but we need to go further on practi- cal action.â€

And then there's the big-ticket pledge from Pierrickâ€™s manifesto: to take on First Bus.

â€œFirst Bus has become worse and worse in my four years at York. Itâ€™s not acceptable.

â€œDisabled students, commuting students and students waiting for the bus between East and West campuses are the most impacted by the inadequate service First Bus is offering.

"And this also means that more students are driving to campus now, and encouraging people to take public transport is central to fighting climate change.â€

Previous Sabbatical Officers have tried and failed to engage with First Bus. Pierrick says: â€œFirst Bus doesnâ€™t treat students with respect. Kelly Balmer [the outgoing Community & Wellbeing Officer] told me that First Bus has cancelled meetings without telling her before.â€

Pierrick believes that a new strategy is needed. â€œFirst Bus has shown that they wonâ€™t listen to students, so the University should engage with First Bus directly rather than leaving it to the Sabbatical Officers,â€ he says.

â€œFirst Bus isnâ€™t a new problem. But their contract with the University ends soon. That presents a perfect opportunity to give First Bus an ultimatum: either you improve or weâ€™ll find someone else.â€

Pierrick stresses that his first move will not be to show First Bus the door. â€œDialogue before more drastic action,â€ he insists.

But, if Pierrick does end up persuading the University to ditch First Bus, which bus company would replace it? â€œAny company offering a better service at a lower price,â€ comes his reply.

Tackling rising rent is also high on Pierrickâ€™s lengthy to-do list. Can he really succeed where so many previous Presidents have failed?

â€œI think that previous Sabbatical Officers have been too polite to the University. The difference is that I love direct action. The things Iâ€™ve done as Environment Officer have all been about instigating the University. Iâ€™m going to make a lot of noise, so there will be more pressure on the University to cap rent than in the past.â€

On election night, Pierrick won the presidency convincingly with almost an outright majority in the first round of votes (YUSU uses Single Transferable Vote for its elections). Could Pierrick be a two-term president? â€œAlready?â€ he smirks. â€œIf I donâ€™t deliver as President, then no. But until Iâ€™ve actually started my first term, itâ€™s way too early to be thinking about a second one.â€

Previous YUSU Presidents have faced major setbacks in trying to implement their lofty manifesto pledges. Pierrick has experience of the inner workings of YUSU, so is he prepared to face resistance to his plans? â€œOf course. Iâ€™m not coming into this role expecting the University and YUSU to listen to everything I say. From day one, I know itâ€™s going to be tough.â€

If he canâ€™t overcome resistance from the University and YUSU, would he be satisfied with just small changes? â€œNo, not at all. But small change is better than no change.â€

Pierrick knows what he wants to do and how much he will have to fight to achieve it. Before he leaves, he ends with a call to action: â€œNo one should have any doubt â€” Iâ€™m ready to go full-on in my campaigns.â€
